image.altText: A crowd of people stand on the street outside an Optus store

items.synopsis: Optus says it "may take a few hours for all services to recover", with the telco yet to identify the root issue behind today's huge outage. Follow live.

title.children: Optus services 'gradually' restored as engineers warn of network vulnerabilities

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A marketing expert says today's Optus outage may do serious reputational damage. Optus also came under fire last year after it was hacked, leading to information leaks affecting more than 2.5 million customers. Australian National University marketing expert Dr Andrew Hughes says this latest incident could do even more damage. "The one last year, by the way, their brand value slipped by around one billion dollars in 2022 — that's how big it was," he says. "So this time around you can sort of expect to have maybe even a bit higher because the people that stayed with them last time, may be thinking again this time, 'You know what, we keep on hearing the same language, but we're seeing the same action as well'."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus could suffer serious reputational damage, marketing expert says

children.content: A marketing expert says today's Optus outage may do serious reputational damage.
Optus also came under fire last year after it was hacked, leading to information leaks affecting more than 2.5 million customers.
Australian National University marketing expert Dr Andrew Hughes says this latest incident could do even more damage.
"The one last year, by the way, their brand value slipped by around one billion dollars in 2022 — that's how big it was," he says.

"So this time around you can sort of expect to have maybe even a bit higher because the people that stayed with them last time, may be thinking again this time, 'You know what, we keep on hearing the same language, but we're seeing the same action as well'."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some of our readers say they still haven't been able to access their mobile and internet services after Optus announced they were restored. These comments were sent to us in the past half hour. WiFi still not working, and mobile data is back but very very shaky. Disappointed they'd blanket say everything is resolved. - Sarah Feels a bit disingenuous from Optus to say "restored" when that clearly isn't 100% so. My Optus NBN is still out, and I've given my equipment a couple of chances to restart in the last half hour - Nick Optus says it's customers should now have their internet back ,However we still have no Internet on hold with Optus😞 - Margaret Bay NBN in Brisbane is still not restored, contrary to what the Optus CEO is saying. Appalling treatment of customers and my last day of being an Optus customer after 18 years. - Pat
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some Optus customers say they're still having trouble accessing services

children.content: Some of our readers say they still haven't been able to access their mobile and internet services after Optus announced they were restored.
These comments were sent to us in the past half hour.
WiFi still not working, and mobile data is back but very very shaky. Disappointed they'd blanket say everything is resolved.
- Sarah
Feels a bit disingenuous from Optus to say "restored" when that clearly isn't 100% so. My Optus NBN is still out, and I've given my equipment a couple of chances to restart in the last half hour
- Nick
Optus says it's customers should now have their internet back ,However we still have no Internet on hold with Optus😞
- Margaret Bay
NBN in Brisbane is still not restored, contrary to what the Optus CEO is saying. Appalling treatment of customers and my last day of being an Optus customer after 18 years.
- Pat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Engineers Australia says the Optus outage has exposed vulnerabilities in Australia's telecommunications networks. Jane MacMaster, who is the Chief Engineer at Engineers Australia, says outages like this create a domino effect on our digital systems and economy. "I think society is heading in a direction where we're very reliant on modern technology and part of the challenge is that technology is becoming increasingly complex and increasingly connected," she says. "So if there's a problem in one part of all our systems it's very easily felt in other parts because the connections are there." Today's outage disrupted everything from trains to hospitals, bank call centres, information lines, and the ability of millions of consumers to access services.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The Optus outage has exposed vulnerabilities in Australia's telco networks, engineers say

children.content: Engineers Australia says the Optus outage has exposed vulnerabilities in Australia's telecommunications networks.
Jane MacMaster, who is the Chief Engineer at Engineers Australia, says outages like this create a domino effect on our digital systems and economy.

"I think society is heading in a direction where we're very reliant on modern technology and part of the challenge is that technology is becoming increasingly complex and increasingly connected," she says.
"So if there's a problem in one part of all our systems it's very easily felt in other parts because the connections are there."
Today's outage disrupted everything from trains to hospitals, bank call centres, information lines, and the ability of millions of consumers to access services.

image.altText: A burnt home in Nauiyu

items.synopsis: Eight people have been arrested from the remote community of Nauiyu amid an eruption of violence and fighting and break-ins. Community members say they are at a loss for solutions.

title.children: Homes burnt and trashed, people forced to leave remote NT community of Nauiyu as unrest re-ignites

image.altText: People taking photos of Uluru

items.synopsis: Businesses say cost-of-living pressures, expensive airfares and concerns around crime are contributing to a slump in tourism in Central Australia, where the drive market in particular is lagging.

title.children: Central Australia sees 'massive drop' in visitor numbers, as new minister flags revitalisation plan

image.altText: A sandstone window with yellow "yes" writing and an Optus sign.

items.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says "a technical network fault" is to blame for the company's nationwide outage on Wednesday, but can't provide more information on the cause before conducting a deeper analysis.

title.children: Optus CEO rejects claims that 600 job cuts were to blame for 'technical network fault' that hit 10 million people

image.altText: A close up shot of crocodile teeth, with brown stains on them

items.synopsis: Northern Territory cattle producer Colin Deveraux knows he is lucky to be alive after being attacked by a 3.2-metre saltwater crocodile.

title.children: 'He shook me like a rag doll': Cattleman survives croc attack by biting back

image.altText: An inflatable pool with a blow up ring floating in it

items.synopsis: A Perth woman who held the heads of both her young children underwater in an inflatable pool is jailed, and banned from ever contacting them again.

title.children: Perth mother jailed after holding children's heads underwater in blow-up pool

image.altText: Composite image of two young men, with police behind them.

items.synopsis: A man who lit bushfires and filmed videos pledging his loyalty to Islamic State is found guilty of terrorism-related offences, but his older brother will walk free after being cleared by a jury.

title.children: Jury delivers mixed verdicts to Melbourne brothers accused of terrorism over small bushfires

image.altText: The crumpled front of a white BMW SUV, surrounded by emergency services tape.

items.synopsis: Police have interviewed the driver at the centre of a tragic crash that killed five people in the regional Victorian town of Daylesford, but no charges have been laid.

title.children: Lawyer for Daylesford crash driver says ‘family man’ is deeply distressed and remains in hospital care

image.altText: Palestinian family reacts following Israeli airstrike

items.synopsis: At least 500 more people, most of them foreign nationals, cross into Egypt after the Rafah border crossing re-opens. Here's how the day's events unfolded.

title.children: DFAT confirms three Australians among new Rafah crossing evacuations, Israel wants 'ultimate security control' over Gaza — as it happened

image.altText: Sign in red dirt reading Arnhem Space Centre.

items.synopsis: The fledgling Arnhem Space Centre in the remote Northern Territory is looking to substantially expand its facilities and launch capacity if it's given the tick of approval.

title.children: One launch a week, 14 launch pads: Massive expansion pegged for remote Australian rocket base

image.altText: Muslim woman wearing a white hijab, red shirt and black jacket, sitting in her home.

items.synopsis: Hanaa Elmobayed was one of 19 Australians who made it out of Gaza through the Rafah crossing with Egypt last weekend. But there were many times the mother of five feared she'd never make it back to her family.

title.children: Hanaa was visiting her mum in Gaza when the war broke out. Now home, she's scarred from what she saw

image.altText: A composite picture of Glenn Maxwell

items.synopsis: Glenn Maxwell's stunning match-winning double century at the Cricket World Cup has been hailed as the greatest ODI innings of all time. Here are the performances he's up against for that title.

title.children: Glenn Maxwell's innings is 'without a doubt' the best of all time — these are the performances it beats

image.altText: A horse-like head emerges in gas and dust from a region of space 1,375 light-years from Earth

items.synopsis: The European Space Agency wows with the first full colour images from the Euclid space telescope, a "dark matter detective" with the specs to rival the famed James Webb.

title.children: 'Revolution for astronomy': New space telescope captures mind-blowing images of distant galaxies

image.altText: A sign saying "caution" in front of an open pit coal mine and power station.

items.synopsis: The gap between climate rhetoric and fossil fuel use is growing, according to a UN report that warns the world's carbon budget has almost been used up.

title.children: Climate disconnect grows wider as fossil fuel use soars to 'double' required level by 2030

image.altText: birds eye view shot of several buildings reduced to grey rubble

items.synopsis: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency (URNWA) says there eight refugee camps in the Gaza Strip, according to the Gaza's health ministry, five have been hit.

title.children: There are eight refugee camps in Gaza — five have reportedly been struck since war with Israel began

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg releases first public statement after release

items.synopsis: Kathleen Folbigg was released from prison in June after being pardoned over the deaths of her four children. A final report after an inquiry into her convictions was released on Wednesday.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg case referred for possible appeal after final conviction report released

image.altText: Front of a car crashed into a tree

items.synopsis: Alleged driver Nicholas Thew to remain behind bars after being charged with a number of offences over a crash in Sydney's south-west that resulted in the deaths of two teenage passengers.

title.children: 'Underlying issues' involved in Sydney car crash that killed two boys, court hears

image.altText: Boris Johnson grimaces while sitting behind a Union Jack flag

items.synopsis: The former UK prime minister's senior advisor says Mr Johnson hoped to show the public COVID-19 did not pose a threat in the early days of the nation's outbreak.

title.children: Former aide says Boris Johnson wanted to be injected with COVID-19 on live TV

image.altText: Large plumes of black smoke erupt behind a fenced off military base

items.synopsis: Firefighting services across WA are being stretched to the limit with dozens of blazes burning already, in a bushfire season the emergency services commissioner says is up to eight weeks ahead of schedule.

title.children: 'A hell of a lot' of fires: WA’s bushfire season arrives up to two months early

image.altText: An older woman, Eileen Kramer, wears a ballgown while sitting in a wheelchair

items.synopsis: Louis Armstrong was nice, and Ella Fitzgerald was not so nice, according to 109-year-old Eileen Kramer who is not planning on hanging up her dancing shoes.

title.children: Draped in white feathers and wearing a pair of sparkly ballet flats, Eileen celebrated her 109th birthday in style

image.altText: Man with no hair.

items.synopsis: The verdict comes after the four-week trial of a man who drove an alleged gunman to and from the home of a Newcastle woman shot dead at her front door.

title.children: Jury finds getaway driver guilty of manslaughter, not murder, over grandmother's slaying

image.altText: police tape

items.synopsis: A jury has heard a planned street fight on the NSW Central Coast lasted less than three seconds before a 13-year-old boy fatally stabbed another 13-year-old boy.

title.children: Teenager stabbed boy, 13, to death with kitchen knife during street fight, court hears

image.altText: The outline of four women, kept anonymous, superimposed over shattered glass

items.synopsis: The deaths of four Aboriginal women examined by a major coronial inquest were equally horrific. But none garnered national attention for very long.

title.children: 'The silence sickens me': Lives of Aboriginal women remembered at domestic violence inquiry

image.altText: Donna Simpson, Josh Cunningham and Vikki Thorn sitting on seats in back garden

items.synopsis: Some fans of an Aussie folk rock band will have to wait a little longer to see them in concert as vocalist Donna Simpson recovers from an e-scooter crash.

title.children: The Waifs push back concert after singer suffers collapsed lung in e-scooter fall

image.altText: A close-up photograph of a burgundy-coloured flying duck orchid

items.synopsis: An amateur photographer has been looking across two states for almost a decade for a small orchid resembling a flying duck. Then a tip from a friend finally ended his long search.

title.children: Nine-year 'duck' hunt ends as photographer snaps elusive orchid

image.altText: A woman uses her phone outside an Optus store as a man looks at his.

items.synopsis: Services are being restored after millions of Optus customers were left without phone and internet services. Here's what we know about the outage.

title.children: What caused the Optus outage, and how long was it down for? Here's what we know

image.altText: Front on view of an icebreaker ship.

items.synopsis: Officials at the Australian Antarctic Division were left scrambling after a decision to block RSV Nuyina from transiting the Tasman Bridge and refuelling close to port, with the true cost of a 660km detour now revealed.

title.children: What should have been a 4km refuelling trip for Australia's icebreaker is now a 660km debacle

image.altText: Abattoirs feeling the pinch

items.synopsis: Meat inspectors and vets are walking off the job today, with the industry saying the strike action will create backlogs that affect domestic and export sectors.

title.children: Abattoir inspectors and vets strike for 'decent pay' as meat industry slams 'unions gone wild'
